thread.section_title: Business News, Economy, Finance & ASX Market News
thread.title: Sydney's fringe office markets tight for space
thread.title_full: Sydney's fringe office markets tight for space

title: Sydney's fringe office markets tight for space
text:
Leighton Holdings has partially offset rising demand for fringe office markets with the start of its headquarters at 177-199 Pacific Highway.
Fringe office markets are some of the most tightly held as residential conversions reduce available space, and the demand is rising from small to medium tenants.
The changing demand in the satellite areas of western Sydney, through the influx of students and new industries, means Parramatta has become a sought-after destination.
There has been negative net absorption in the western Sydney market for some, although new offices, such as at the Westfield Parramatta shopping centre, will add to the mix when completed in 2018-19.
While residential sites are overtaking office sites, in North Sydney, Leighton Holdings has balanced the equilibrium with the start of its headquarters at 177-199 Pacific Highway, which is owned by Singapore's Suntec REIT.
Advertisement JLL Australia says the Sydney fringe office market has the tightest total vacancy rate of 6.8 per cent, across the 19 office markets it tracks in Australia.
JLL's director of leasing in NSW, Andrew Westaway, said demand for quality, creative office space from technology, advertising, media, and education companies had driven inquiries and activities across the fringe market and exerted downward pressure on vacancies.
One of the latest groups likely to look at city fringe locations is Nine Entertainment, after the recent sale of the Channel Nine studios in Willoughby in Sydney's northern suburbs, through CBRE.
Nine has a lease deal for five years.
However, a spokesman said the station was expected to release a brief for new locations "by the end of this year".
"Tenants are attracted and remain in the fringe for the creative premises, high level of amenity, public transportation infrastructure and affordable rental levels relative to the CBD. Furthermore, a high proportion of workers live in surrounding areas, allowing them to walk or bicycle to work," Mr Westaway said.
JLL's head of strategic research, Australia, Andrew Ballantyne, said a shortage of contiguous options and a limited supply pipeline over the medium term meant upward pressure would be placed on rents in the Sydney fringe office market over the next 12 months.
JLL's numbers show that prime gross effective rents have increased 6.4 per cent over the 2014-15 financial year.
"Furthermore, given the proximity to the CBD and strong demand for residential developments across the Sydney metropolitan area, we will see increased developer interest for office assets with adaptive reuse potential," Mr Ballantyne said.
"We have already seen this with Aqualand's most recent acquisition of the No. 8 Revy site in Pyrmont for $180 million, which is to be redeveloped into luxury apartments."
Mr Westaway said technology and education were growth sectors in NSW and there were several organisations on a rapid expansion path which would drive leasing activity in 2015-16.
Savills' research team said the north shore market shrank by 24,734 square metres throughout 2014, representing a reduction in office space by 1.1 per cent.
The latest Property Council of Australia numbers show the overall vacancy rate for the combined north shore is 8.5 per cent.
"In the 12 months to June 2015, Savills identified 41,615 square metres of leasing activity in the north shore market. This is down 68.1 per cent on the 12 months prior, and down on the five-year average (86,890 square metres). The majority of these leases, of about 64 per cent of space, were leased in the North Ryde precinct," Savills researchers said.
